THE Secretary explained that, owing to the number of questions of all sorts which were coming up for the decision of theWar Cabinet, congestion would very likely ensue unless some ofthe minor points, instead of being laid before the whole Cabinet,could be set aside for the consideration of separate Committeesconsisting of members of the War Cabinet and others.The War Cabinet decided that This procedure should be accepted, subject to the proviso that any great question of principle would have to be considered by thewhole War Cabinet, and the course as detailed below shouldbe adopted in reference to the following questions : (a.) The question of the Naval Shipbuilding Programme(Memorandum by the Secretary of the Admiralty, dated the5th March, 1917-Paper G.T.-105) should be dealt withby the Chancellor of the Exchequer and the First sea lord of the Admiralty, working in consultation with theShipping Controller, with Fleet Paymaster P. H. Row as secretary.(6.) La reference to the supply of heavy guns to "Roumania (lettertoruns to Koumama. from ^ Roumanian Minister to the Prime Minister, dated the 7thFebruary, 1917, Paper G.T.-87), the War Cabinet decided that-The matter should await the general decision on the programme for Russia, which was being put forward by Lord Milner'mission.New Airship. 3, in reference to the proposed new airship (War Cabinet 92,Minute 5), the Prime Minister stated that he had been in com-munication with the First Lord of the Admiralty on the subject, andit was thought that the scheme was too large to be embarked uponduring the present war. The War Cabinet decided that The proposed construction of the new airship should not beundertaken.Transport Workers' 4. The Secretary of State for War, in connection with the battalions. allotment of men for labour in Transport Workers' Battalions (WarCabinet 73, Minute 14 ; War Cabinet 84, Minute 4), requested adecision as to whether he should give priority to the completion to strength of the Labour Battalions in France or the Transport. Workers' Battalions in England. The War Cabinet decided that Since it was possible to employ foreign labour abroad, whilst itwas not possible to do so at home, the Transport Workers'Battalions at home should be a prior charge on the menat the disposal of the Secretary of State for War.(Initialled) D.
